Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Disaster Recovery Decision Making in Remote Tourism-dependent Communities

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: Hurricanes disrupt community vitality when significant damage and destruction occurs to the built environment, particularly in remote, tourism-dependent coastal communities. Immediately following the impacts to homes, businesses, and infrastructure, tourism business owners and employees begin to make recovery decisions that affect the resilience of coastal communities. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project examines the factors and information networks that influence recovery decisions in Ocracoke and Hatteras, North Carolina, which were substantially impacted by Hurricane Dorian (September 2019). The remote nature of these communities makes them particularly vulnerable, as their transportation network is built upon a single state highway and/or ferry service that, when damaged, can affect access to recovery resources. Their dependence on tourism also makes them economically vulnerable as tourism benefits (e.g., jobs, tax revenues) rely on transportation access and lodging availability. Similar disaster-related impacts may become increasingly common in other coastal tourism-dependent communities due to potential increases in storm intensity and frequency in conjunction with sea-level rise. By identifying the factors and networks that influence early recovery decisions, this project contributes to NSF’s mission to advance national welfare and promote the progress of science. Specifically, this study increases the understanding of individual disaster recovery decisions within the tourism sector, which cumulatively influence a community’s ability to reestablish its built environment and economic base. This study also identifies the communication pathways that enable more informed near-term recovery decisions, which can be activated in future disaster response, tourism crisis management, and community resiliency building efforts.<br/><br/>The goal of our project is to compare the factors and information networks that influence information processing and recovery decision making in two remote post-disaster tourism-dependent communities. This project has four objectives: (1) documenting various factors that influence tourism stakeholders’ recovery decisions; (2) identifying information networks accessed by tourism stakeholders to inform recovery decisions; (3) evaluating the extent to which recovery information activated through those networks is processed; and (4) understanding decision making pathways that influence risk perceptions and intended recovery decisions. These objectives will be accomplished by integrating the Risk Information Seeking and Processing (RISP) model with Social Network Analysis (SNA) in the analysis of data generated during in-depth interviews with tourism business owners, employees, and community leaders, as well as state emergency response officials. Data will be thematically analyzed for factors and RISP model predictors that influence recovery decisions, and information networks will be mapped using SNA to identify influential pathways for recovery decision making. Additionally, community-level data will be compared to identify if, and how, varying infrastructure damage and access to recovery resources impact decision making, which will enhance the transferability of our findings. Collecting these data in a near-term post-disaster context is critical, as the state of a tourism destination (e.g., availability of recovery funds, others’ recovery decisions) impacts the availability of future decision options. The findings will reveal the factors and information pathways that influence disaster recovery decisions in a synergistic examination of business and household recovery decisions. More specifically, the findings will identify the ways in which information processing of current and prior experiences, perceptions of workforce capacity and recovery of the built environment, network support availability, and anticipated tourism demand influence recovery decision making, as well as expose capacity needs to maintain the tourism industry in near-term, post-disaster contexts.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Remote tourism-dependent communities are vulnerable to disasters due to their reliance on tourism as an economic driver and limited access to outside resources. In the wake of disasters such as hurricanes, which can be further compounded by other crises (e.g., the COVID-19 pandemic), community members must make decisions on how, or whether, to recover from these events. In remote tourism-dependent communities the viability of the local economy depends on tourism business owners and workforce members' recovery decisions. Therefore, we used the Risk Information Seeking and Processing (RISP) Model to examine the factors and information networks that influence information processing and recovery decision making in remote post-disaster tourism-dependent communities.

Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 51 community stakeholders in Ocracoke and Hatteras, NC who faced recovery decisions following Hurricane Dorian and during the COVID-19 pandemic. Both Ocracoke and Hatteras are remote barrier island communities. Hatteras has access to only one primary state highway and Ocraoke is accessible only by ferry. Ocracoke had greater impacts due to flooding from Hurricane Dorian, but both communities were equally impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Community members who were interviewed included tourism business owners, tourism workforce members, residents of the communities not employed in tourism, non-resident property owners (who rent their homes in communities as tourist lodgings), and leaders at the local and state levels. We additionally conducted analysis of local media content (e.g., local newspaper articles) as an information source for decision-making. 

Thematic analysis of the interview data, guided by RISP, revealed that community members largely rely on local sources (e.g., individuals in adjacent communities, county level offices) to get decision-making information. In addition to the information provided in these local information sources, key influencers of recovery decisions include place attachment and past experience with disasters. It is notable that past experience does not necessarily heighten risk perceptions, but instead sets a baseline for community members to assess the current disaster against. Social network analysis indicated that key central figures in local communities served as trusted information sources in the recovery decision making process. Interestingly, local media sources (e.g., newspapers) do not provide local community members with information for decision making, but do serve outside audiences (e.g., prior visitors, non-resident property owners) and act as an amplifier for the communities' needs during disaster recovery, helping to garner national and even international attention and aid. 

This work also revealed valuable findings related to how a second crisis, namely the COVID-19 pandemic, can influence disaster recovery decisions. The pandemic began while Ocracoke and Hatteras were still in the process of recovering from Hurricane Dorian. The impacts of the hurricane had curtailed the fall 2019 tourist season and raised questions of whether the islands would be ready to welcome visitors for the start of the 2020 summer season. The lockdowns and supply chain disruptions of the early days of the pandemic slowed rebuilding efforts, but when access to the islands was opened to non-residents both communities saw high levels of demand for vacation rental properties, as visitors saw these remote places as a "safe" location to work and school remotely, despite their limited access to healthcare facilities. This massive increase in demand forced community leaders and business owners to decide if they would open their doors to non-residents. While systematic information processing was applied in this decision making, many sources of information were carefully considered, the communities opened to visitors, even while they continued to recover from the hurricane. This decision led to considerable economic benefits from doing so, which helped to recover losses from the hurricane impacts, but raises questions about how community members will process recovery decisions in future compounded crises.

This work advances the knowledge of how decision making occurs in the context of a compounded crisis (hurricane and health pandemic) in remote tourism-dependent communities. It represents a novel application of the RISP model to this context and offers insight into what can be done to support community members' decision making in future disasters. Ultimately this work revealed the importance of local information sources and social connectivity within remote tourism-dependent communities. These findings point to a need for a centralized information resource that community members can turn to when making disaster recovery decisions.
